places.picture_description:
Miklós Barabás: Savka Obrenović
Residence of Princess Ljubica
Belgrade

"This Biedermeier portrait, painted in Vienna, shows Jelisaveta Savka Obrenović, the third child and the youngest daughter of Prince Miloš and Princess Ljubica. She is depicted in a silk dress and a libade trimmed with fur, also known as škurteljka. This is the only traditional element in her dress. The medallion with a portrait of prince Miloš supported by her hand alludes to her ancestors. According to tradition, Prince Miloš was particularly closely related to Savka, who was his favourite child. At the age of seventeen she got married to Baron Jovan Nikolić of Rudna, with whom she had five sons."
https://izi.travel/en/286d-miklos-barabas-savka-obrenovic/en

name: Čokor Jovan (1849-1911)
description:
Jovan Čokor was born as Johann Nepomuk Csokor on 4 April 1849, and was baptised on 6 April in the Catholic church of St. Leopold. He was born in house no. 371 (today Große Stadtgutgasse 11) in Leopoldstadt.His father was Aleksandar Čokor and his mother Anna (Schindler). He started his education at Sremski Karlovci by his uncle, archimandrite Julijan Čokor, and stayed there from 1854 to 1864. After that he finished high school in Pest in 1866 and studies of medicine in Vienna. He was promoted as Dr. of Medicine in 1873. In 1875 he graduated in veterinary science, received an assistant position at the Department of Anatomy and Physiology in Vienna, was entrusted with lectures on histology and parasitology and introduced histological-microscopic teaching at University. 
Jovan  married Emilie Müller in Vienna on 28 July 1877. They had 5 children: 
Emilie Sofia Maria Čokor (6 June 1878), 
Franz Theodor Čokor (8 September 1885 - 5 January 1969), 
Johann Čokor (22 October 1886 - 1915),
Eugenie Čokor (24 November 1887 - 1979),
Sofie Čokor (6 July 1891 - 1967). 

From 1876 as a temporary and from 1879 as a permanent lecturer at the Chair of Zoology, Čokor was appointed in 1880 professor of general pathology and forensic veterinary medicine in Vienna. In 1884 he deepened his knowledge with Robert Koch in Berlin. Already from 1889 he was also an eminent Professor of infectious and parasitic diseases and turned more to parasitology. In 1906 a chair for this discipline was established. Čokor also founded and widely publicized diagnostic vaccine stations. In addition, he taught from 1890 as a Privatdozent and from 1895 as a Professor of Veterinary Medicine at the University of Vienna. In 1909 he retired as professor and councilor. 
He wrote for several scientific journals, namely "Österreichische Vierteljahresschrift für wissenschaftliche Veterinärkunde", "Allgemeine Wiener Medizinische Zeitung" and "Wiener Wochenschrift".He published a "Lehrbuch der Gerichtliche Thierheilkunde" (1898, 2nd ed. 1902 as "Textbook of Judicial Animal Medicine and Veterinary Law”).
He received the Knight's Cross in 1898 and in 1909 the officer's cross of the Franz Joseph Order. He was knight of the Serbian Order of Saint Sava anda member of the Society of Doctors as well as honorary member of the Serbian Society of Doctors in Belgrade. Finally, he bore the title of Hofrat.
He died on 7 January 1911 in his apartment in Mödling and was buried on the local cemetery.

name: Petrović Dimitrije (1799-1854)
description:
Dimitrije Petrović (1799-1854) was an academic sculptor in Vienna. He was born in Baja and came to Vienna in 1819. He studied first with Joseph Klieber and in 1821 at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna. Here Petrović received two awards in 1823. After that he worked with Johann Nepomuk Schaller, and his capital work was a statue of Graf Kinsky from 1830, which was presented in the Imperial Military Academy building in Wiener Neustadt (Wiener Neustadt – Theresianische Militärakademie. Franz Graf Kinsky. Büste 1829 beauftragt und 1830 von Johann Nepomuk Schaller geschaffen, gegossen von Demeter Petrowitsch). From 1831 he worked alone and created many sculptures among them two of Christ for Prince Miloš and one for the Metropoliten of Sremski Karlovci. Also he worked on Altars in chapels for Graf Schwarzenberg. 
Petrović died at the age of 55 on 25 December 1854 in his apartment in Leopoldstadt No. 378. He was buried two days later on 27 December on St Marx cemetery in the Orthodox part.  His son was the famous painter Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907).

name: Arlov Ritter von Sava (1827-1903)
description: Sava Arlov was Field Marshal Lieutenant (FML) and Austrian nobleman. Arlow was born on the Military Frontier in Petrinja (today in Croatia) on 26 October 1827. In 1848 he joined the Army. After the Battle of Custozza he was decorated with the Order of the Iron Crown 3th grade with War decoration (Orden der Eisernen Krone 3 Klasse mit der Kriegsdecoration). On 12 June 1867 he was enobled by Knighthood with title the “Ritter von” by the Austrian Emperor. In 1882 he was decorated with the Knight cross of the Leopold Order (Ritterkreuz des Leopold Ordens). He was promoted to the rank of General Major in 1883 and to the rank of Field Marshal Lieutenant in 1887. In 1888 on his 40 jubilee in the army he was decorated by Emperor Franz Josef I with the Order of the Iron Crown 2th grade with War decoration (Orden der Eisernen Krone 2 Klasse mit der Kriegsdecoration). Soon after that he retired and died in his appartment in Posthorngasse 5 (1030) on 30 May 1903. After the procession to the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity on Fleischmarkt 13 (1010) he was buried on 2 June 1903 on Vienna Central cemetery.

name: Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota Djordje (1843-1908)
description:
Djordje Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota, (Georg von Gyurkovics) (1843-1908) was a journalist, member of the Hungarian and Croatian Parliaments, member of the Serbian National Congress and member of the Serbian Church Community Council in Vienna.  Since 1876 Djurković was an editor and journalist in the Viennese newspaper “Presse”.  He died in Budapest on 25 May 1908, where he was editor of the newspaper “Neues Pester Journal”. 
He published in Vienna:
-Die Schauspielschule des Wiener Conservatoriums 1874 - 1876 (F. Beck, Wien 1876)
-Eine Studie über Lessing's Laokoon (Rosner, Wien 1876)
-Bosnien und die Nebenländer: Schilderungen von Land und Leuten zwischen der Donau und der Adria (Wien 1879)
-Albanien. Schilderungen von Land und Leute. Mit 3 Illustrationen (Hölder,Wien 1881)

name: Petrović Ladislav Eugen (1839-1907)
description: Ladislav Eugen Petrović was born on 25 January 1839 in Vienna and was a son of the famous sculptor Demeter Petrovits (1799 -1854). He was landscape painter, illustrator, and caricaturist. From 1857 to 1861 he was a student of the Academy of Fine Arts, where he devoted himself to landscape and architectural painting. He drew for the newspapers ("Illustrierte Zeitung" from Leipzig, "L'Illustration" from Paris) and illustrated books, created a series of Viennese topographical oil paintings and from 1887 Watercolors (reproduced in full color, including the series "Wiener Ansichten", "Wiener Bilderbögen", "Erinnerung an Wien" and "Wiener Typen"). He died on 1 April 1907 in his apartment in Landstraßer Hauptstraße 21.  He lived there since 03 December 1894 with his wife Mathilde (born Nowotny). He was born Orthodox and converted to Catholicism on 1 December 1894. Before his last place of living he lived in Erdbergstrasse 3.

name: Mandić Emanuel
description: Mandić Emanuel, was General-Intendant in Austro-Hungarian army. He received the Knight cross of the Franz Josef Order in 1880 , the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd grade in 1904, when he had retired.  In 1910 he became Section chief (Sektionschef). He was active in the Serbian Orthodox Church community of St Sava in Vienna. On 16 February 1913 Mandić was present in the Greek-Orthodox Church of Holly Trinity on the Fleischmarkt in Vienna when Dimitrije Branković, the new Bishop of Zara was promoted and gave his first apostolic speech there.  On 29 January 1908 he was present in St. Sava Church at the celebration of water consecration.

name: Zastavniković Gedeon (1824-1869)
description:
Gedeon Zastavniković Ritter von was General Major born in Kula (Military Frontier) in 1824. After his military education in Graz he was Adjutant of Ban Jelačić. Later, Zastavniković became commander of the Slunj Regiment and commander of the Militay Frontier. Following this duty, he went to Vienna, where he worked in the Ministry of War. 
He died on 6 January 1869 at the age of 45 and was buried two days later in Orthodox part of the St. Marx cemetery in Vienna. Zastavniković died in his apartment Landstraßer Hauptstraße 68.

name: Despinić von Konstantin
description: Since 27 December 1862 Konstantin von Despinić was one of the owners in the Vienesse Company B.Despinits & comp., which traded with diverse products, especially with meat products. In that time he still lived in Kovin (Military Frontier, today Serbia). The other owners were his brothers Vasilije von Despinić, merchant from Vienna, and Jovan von Despinić as well as Aleksandar Marković from Kovin. The address of the Company was Landstraßer Hauptstraße 43.  In 1888 Vasilije and Jovan were deleted from the register because they had died and at the same time were registered as owners Aron and Pavle von Despinić from Kovin.  From 7 November 1879 Konstantin von Despinić was the owner of the Company C. Despinits in Simmeringer Hauptstrasse 16. On 29 April 1898 the Company was deleted from the register.  Von Despinić was member of the Serbian Orthodox church community council in the time of the building of the Church in the 1880/90´s and president of the community council from 1885 until 1888. Here lived Serbian merchant and president of the Serbian Orthodox church community council Konstantin von Despinić with his family. His last Viennese address was Landstraßer Hauptstraße 65. In this house were born his son Radovan (9 June 1877) and daughter Sophie (4 April 1891). The building still exists.

description: Jekatarina- Katica Obrenović (1826-1848) was the daughter of Prince Miloš's brother, Jevrem Obrenović. She died in Vienna and after mass in the St George church  was buried on St. Marx cemetery on 27 July 1848.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Wilhelmine (1847-1918)
description: Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna (born Hirsch) (1847-1918) was an Opera singer. She married Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna in Vienna on 18 May 1869. After her husband’s death she lived mostly in Baden near Vienna and after her daughter Jovana Duka de Kadar died in 1917, Wilhelmine Nikolić became her legal inheritor.Jovana´s husband Baron Geza Duka de Kadar died earlier, in 1913. Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna died in Vienna on 25 March 1918 in the Sanatorium Svetlin,Leonhardgase 3-5 (1030).
